Award.AwardTitle: Glucocorticoid hormone entrainment of prefrontal cortex circadian function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Optimal brain function depends on a daily cycle of fluctuating operation (a circadian rhythm) and synchronization of that rhythm to the environmental day-night cycle. A specific region of the mammalian brain, the suprachiasmatic nucleus, is responsible for coordinating the brain's circadian rhythms. Little is known about how this coordination happens. This project examines the circadian function of the prefrontal cortex, a brain region involved in complex thinking, such as planning and decision-making, and the control of mood and emotions. The project will test the innovative hypothesis that a specific hormone (glucocorticoid hormone) serves as communicator between the suprachiasmatic nucleus and the prefrontal cortex. The project will use a systems biology approach to determine how glucocorticoid hormones regulate prefrontal cortex circadian rhythms in rats. The project also will use cutting-edge manipulations of prefrontal cortex gene expression to discern the mechanisms by which circadian rhythms contribute to optimal prefrontal cortex function. The studies will result in new understanding of glucocorticoid hormone physiology and its role in the coordination of brain circadian function. This new understanding could have significant benefit for society by promoting new strategies to combat disturbed circadian function, such as occurs with night-shift work, jet lag, seasonal extremes, aging, and certain disorders. The research will provide excellent research opportunities for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students from diverse backgrounds through an ongoing partnership with the University of Colorado's STEM Center for Learning and Diversity. Findings from this research will be disseminated to the scientific community and the general public through research team presentations on campus, at regional and national scientific meetings and community forums, and postings on a public lab web-site.

The medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) is central to the advanced cognitive function in mammalian species. Strong diurnal variation in cognitive function suggests that mPFC operation is under circadian control. The mPFC lacks direct neural connection with the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN), the master clock in the brain, but has high expression of glucocorticoid receptors, supporting the prospect that corticosterone (CORT) participates in the entrainment of mPFC rhythmic clock gene expression. Preliminary data show dynamic modulation of mPFC clock gene expression that depends on the prior daily profile of diurnal circulating patterns of CORT. Moreover, a mPFC-dependent memory task, conditioned fear extinction, displays a diurnal variation in expression that is absent in adrenalectomized rats. Based on these supporting preliminary data, the project will determine whether: 1) CORT contributes to entrainment of mPFC rhythmic clock gene expression, 2) an appropriately timed daily CORT pulse is necessary for normal entrainment of diurnal variation in mPFC-dependent conditioned fear extinction, and 3) CORT entrainment of mPFC-mediated conditioned fear extinction depends on CORT activation of mPFC glucocorticoid receptors and rhythmic mPFC clock gene expression. The proposed research will provide excellent scientific training opportunities for a diverse group of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. A range of avenues will be used for dissemination of the findings of this project and their value to society.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Each of us has a Master biological clock in our body that orchestrates the daily activity and function of every cell and system of our body. These daily fluctuations in the various functions of our body are called circadian rhythms. Without this Master Clock those rhythms are lost and all bodily function becomes impaired. Over the last 20 years neuroscientists have learned a lot about this Master clock. We now know where it is – it is located deep in the base of our brains (in the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus). We know how it operates – it depends on the cellular function of a class of genes called clock genes. But we still don’t know how this master clock communicates with and controls the rest of the body. The focus of this research was on the circadian control of the prefrontal cortex, a brain region that is largely responsible for our most advanced cognitive (brain) function, that includes decision making, problem solving and formulating complex plans. This brain region is also vital for emotion-related learning and emotional control. In recent years, the Spencer lab found support for the prefrontal cortex to have its own internal clock, that like the Master Clock, also depends on clock gene function. The overall research goal of this project was to characterize the regulation and function of clock gene expression in the mammalian (laboratory rat) medial prefrontal cortex. The project tested the innovative hypothesis that an appropriately timed daily pulse of the glucocorticoid hormone corticosterone provides a critical timing signal that contributes to the Master clock-dependent entrainment of rhythmic medial prefrontal cortex clock gene expression. In addition, we tested the prospect that this rhythmic clock gene expression underlies daily variation in medial prefrontal cortex dependent cognitive processes and associated behaviors. An additional goal of this project was to provide quality neuroscience/neuroendocrine research training to high school, undergraduate and graduate college students, with a targeted effort for inclusion of trainees that come from social groups and perspectives that are under-represented in biology and neuroscience related careers. This research goal was largely accomplished by this 5 year research project. We discovered that normal rhythmic and oscillatory clock gene expression in the prefrontal cortex depends on the specific time of day when daily pulses of systemic corticosterone occur. In contrast daily pulses of corticosterone that occur around the time of day when endogenous corticosterone secretion is low are very disruptive to normal prefrontal cortex clock gene expression. We also discovered that a prefrontal cortex dependent emotional learning task, conditioned fear extinction memory performance, is regulated in a daily fashion that depends on the presence of both a circadian pattern of corticosterone secretion as well as an elevation of corticosterone immediately after post extinction training. We believe that the corticosterone-entrained molecular clock in the medial prefrontal cortex sets the stage on a daily basis for an enhanced response at one specific time of day (during the rat’s active phase) to the post-extinction training elevation in corticosterone. We also found that the normal clock gene expression in the medial prefrontal cortex is necessary for the superior conditioned fear extinction memory observed in rats trained and tested during their active phase. Other secondary findings include: 1) there are both corticosterone-dependent and corticosterone-independent mechanisms by which acute stress can alter the function of local circadian clocks found in cortical and subcortical brain regions, and 2) there are dynamic corticosterone-dependent daily changes in oligodendrocyte activity (cell type in the brain responsible for producing the neuronal myelin sheath) that varies with time of day and moderate psychological stress. Importantly, this 5-year project also supported the primary training of 4 graduate students, 20 undergraduate students (7 from underrepresented ethnic groups in STEM – 3 African American, 3 Hispanic, and 1 Native American), 5 high school students (1 Hispanic) and 4 postbaccalaureate students. Seven of these undergraduate students have graduated, and four plan to graduate, with honors in Neuroscience based on an honors thesis research project that they conducted in this laboratory during this time period.
